You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News. This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News. I'm John Ydstie. What were the Americas like in 1491, before Columbus landed? So has there been any reaction from the US?

Oh, that I heard. That was an Israeli army tank?

Where the soldiers have been?

With your experience in mind, what are you telling them?

Technology has always driven the way we cook; not always for the better--think the microwave. But a new generation of chefs is using equipment you'd never imagine to forge what they consider a new cuisine. Call it special-effects food. You can get a sampling at a new restaurant in Chicago's trendy Lincoln Park neighborhood; it's called Alinea. And we thought we'd take you there, since it's hard to spot if you're just strolling down North Halsted Street. Is there a sign out front? Did I miss it?

That's Alinea's chef, Grant Achatz. He sat down with us just before the doors opened one recent evening, while staff did some last-minute vacuuming and laid out menus on an elegant sideboard. Like everything here, the menus are minimalist: no prices, no description, just a series of words. One entree reads `Bison, beets, blueberries, burning cinnamon.' Burning cinnamon?
How would you describe, in general, the food you serve here? Can someone peg it?
Is that even colder than a subzero fridge?
And what does that allow you to do?
Can you give me an example? What's a dish that would come out of that freezer?
Can we see your kitchen?
Can you show us?
We walk into the elegant, custom-designed kitchen, a wide open space for all to see. So what are the specials tonight?
And it's not going to fall apart when I do that?

Also on offer tonight: puffed lobster. Achatz describes it as a lobster-flavored Cheeto; it's surprisingly subtle. A lot of Alinea is about creating small surprises. You have something called the Tour that's how many courses?
And how long should it take someone to get through that?
And what did you think about?
Do you still remember that?
What happens?
What do you mean?
How did they react when you approached them?
Well, I mean, this leads to a touchy-feely question. We've been talking about your father and your understanding of him, but have you come to understand yourself a little differently through this?
And, Mr. Korb, would you say the all-volunteer Army is in trouble? And if it is, how serious is it?

Well, what are some possible solutions here, would you say? If there are these military shortfalls, what would you suggest?
They've also talked about increasing bonuses for people in certain highly valued slots within the military. Is that a good idea?

There's been a lot of talk alongside these shortfalls in the recruiting that we've been hearing about that the overall size of the military needs to be increased. So how do you do that in this context?
Mr. Albright, how significant a move is this that Iran has restarted its nuclear fuel cycle?
Now this first step that they undertook today, what does it mean? What have they done exactly?
Now other parts of this plant, though, are under IAEA seal. Isn't that right?
We mentioned this emergency meeting scheduled for tomorrow by the IAEA in Vienna. What do you expect to come of that? Could they do anything in the short term that would put a stop to this?
And is there an appetite within the Security Council to take this on?
If the goal of the Iranians is, in fact, to develop nuclear weapons, how far away would you estimate they are in that process?
Can you tell me, first, what have you found in your testing?
So is it fair to say that the success with this particular vaccine then is, really, only temporary?

But, obviously, you've got to have enough doses of a vaccine to make a difference and have it in the right places where there might be an outbreak. How much of this exists now, and how are you going to go about making more?
And are these two million vaccines in the US?
And what about--how soon could this vaccine make its way to the area that's been most affected by this flu so far, which is Asia?
Can you tell me what does this law do?
I mean, what is your fear out of this ruling if a state didn't pass legislation like you have? How would you see this ruling playing out then? What's your fear?
What about some who might say that they fear some important and needed economic development projects now won't be able to go forward?
Is this then a non-partisan issue?

Now some critics have argued that your new law doesn't go far enough; that actually a big loophole has been created. And as I understand it, the law you signed there in Alabama says that the state can still condemn property in cases of blight. Who defines blight?

MARTHA WEXLER reporting: Well, Jennifer, you know, the Russian naval commanders have been saying now for the last couple of days that they are in contact with the crew and they said they heard from them just several hours ago. And how do you know that bin Laden might be targeting them? I mean, how has this been documented?

As you travel through Europe, I mean, are you hearing from imams and Muslim clerics about this whole notion of radicalizing the second generation of Muslims there?
So what, if anything, can we surmise about the problem right now?
Well, did the court today announce this hospitalization?
And any indication--have they said, given any indication of how long he might remain in the hospital?

NPR legal affairs correspondent Nina Totenberg. The China National Offshore Oil Corporation, C-N-O-O-C or CNOOC (pronounced see-nook), is trying to buy the US oil company Unocal. So is Chevron.
